entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 10 Graph Neural Networks
entry.content:
GNN - graph neural networks

Intuition: how to propagate information over the neighbors in a non-linear manner.

Graph Embeddings as Matrix Factorization

Linear embeddings correspond to SVD of the similarity matrices chosen in the objective.

For adjacency-based similarity, the best linear ddd-dimensional embedding corresponds to the projection of the dataset into the ddd directions associated to the top-ddd singular values:

ifÂ SVD(A)=UÎ£VâŠ¤thenÂ theÂ embeddingÂ matrixÂ Z=UdÎ£d\text{if }SVD(\mathbf A)=\mathbf U\Sigma\mathbf V^\top\\\text{then the embedding matrix }\mathbf Z=\mathbf U_d\Sigma_difÂ SVD(A)=UÎ£VâŠ¤thenÂ theÂ embeddingÂ matrixÂ Z=Udâ€‹Î£dâ€‹

Question: Does there exist a matrix that, once factorized, would be approximately equivalent to run gradient descent over the non-linear objective?

NetMF

DeepWalk, one of the most popular random-walk embedding methods.

A random-walk approach samples random walks using a certain strategy RRR.

A random-walk embedding method optimizes the likelihood that a node jjj is reachable from a random-walk starting from node iii.

DeepWalkâ€™s strategy is to generate random-walks of length LLL and then generate pairs of co-occuring nodes in a window of size TTT. The co-occurences are stored in a multiset D\mathcal DD.

Pseudo-code:

  • for each n=1,2,â‹¯â€‰,Nn=1,2,\cdots,Nn=1,2,â‹¯,N do
    • pick w1nw_1^nw1nâ€‹ according to probability distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1â€‹)
    • generate vertex sequence (w1n,â‹¯â€‰,wLn)(w_1^n,\cdots,w_L^n)(w1nâ€‹,â‹¯,wLnâ€‹) of length LLL by random walk on network GGG
    • for each j=1,2,â‹¯â€‰,Lâˆ’Tj=1,2,\cdots,L-Tj=1,2,â‹¯,Lâˆ’T do
      • for each r=1,â‹¯â€‰,Tr=1,\cdots,Tr=1,â‹¯,T do
        • add vertex-context pair (wjn,wj+rn)(w_j^n,w_{j+r}^n)(wjnâ€‹,wj+rnâ€‹) to multi-set D\mathcal DD
        • add vertex-context pair (wj+rn,wjn)(w_{j+r}^n,w_{j}^n)(wj+rnâ€‹,wjnâ€‹) to multi-set D\mathcal DD

The first vertex of the random-walk w1nw_1^nw1nâ€‹ is sampled from a prior distribution p(w1)p(w_1)p(w1â€‹) that in undirected, connected bipartite graphs correspond to p(i)=di/2âˆ£Eâˆ£p(i)=d_i/2|E|p(i)=diâ€‹/2âˆ£Eâˆ£.

This process and the relative transformation through softmax corresponds to a similarity matrix. We can represent the similarity among two nodes i,ji,ji,j as

\log\left(\frac{\text{(# of RW between i and j)}\cdot\text{(# of node/context pairs)}}{k\text{(# of occurrences of i)}\cdot\text{(# of occurrences of j)}}\right)\\=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)

where kkk is the number of negative samples.

Understand this formula:

  • First partition the set of multi-set D\mathcal DD of pairs of nodes co-occurring in walks into two set Drâ†’\mathcal D_{r\rarr}Drâ†’â€‹ and Drâ†\mathcal D_{r\larr}Drâ†â€‹

    Drâ†’={(w,c):(w,c)âˆˆD,w=wjn,c=wj+rn}Drâ†={(w,c):(w,c)âˆˆD,c=wj+rn,w=wjn}\mathcal D_{r\rarr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,w=w_j^n,c=w_{j+r}^n\}\\\mathcal D_{r\larr}=\{(w,c):(w,c)\in\mathcal D,c=w_{j+r}^n,w=w_j^n\}Drâ†’â€‹={(w,c):(w,c)âˆˆD,w=wjnâ€‹,c=wj+rnâ€‹}Drâ†â€‹={(w,c):(w,c)âˆˆD,c=wj+rnâ€‹,w=wjnâ€‹}

  • Then observe that

    logâ¡(#(i,j)âˆ£Dâˆ£k#(i)#(j))=logâ¡(#(i,j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£k(#(i)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£)(#(j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£))#(i,j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£=12Tâˆ‘r=1T(#(i,j)râ†’âˆ£Dâˆ£râ†’+#(i,j)râ†âˆ£Dâˆ£râ†)\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)|\mathcal D|}{k\#(i)\#(j)}\right)=\log\left(\frac{\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|}{k(\#(i)\div|\mathcal D|)(\#(j)\div|\mathcal D|)}\right)\\\#(i,j)\div|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}+\frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\right)log(k#(i)#(j)#(i,j)âˆ£Dâˆ£â€‹)=log(k(#(i)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£)(#(j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£)#(i,j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£â€‹)#(i,j)Ã·âˆ£Dâˆ£=2T1â€‹r=1âˆ‘Tâ€‹(âˆ£Dâˆ£râ†’â€‹#(i,j)râ†’â€‹â€‹+âˆ£Dâˆ£râ†â€‹#(i,j)râ†â€‹â€‹)

    where the latter observation comes from âˆ£Drâ†’âˆ£/âˆ£Dâˆ£=âˆ£Drâ†âˆ£/âˆ£Dâˆ£=12T|\mathcal D_{r\rarr}|/|\mathcal D|=|\mathcal D_{r\larr}|/|\mathcal D|=\frac{1}{2T}âˆ£Drâ†’â€‹âˆ£/âˆ£Dâˆ£=âˆ£Drâ†â€‹âˆ£/âˆ£Dâˆ£=2T1â€‹.

  • The observe what happens as the length of random walk Lâ†’âˆL\rarr\infty%Lâ†’âˆ. We first define the random walk matrix P=Î”âˆ’1A\mathbf P=\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf AP=Î”âˆ’1A. The volume of a graph GGG is the sum of the entries of adjacency matrix vol(G)=âˆ‘iâˆ‘jai,j\text{vol}(G)=\sum_i\sum_ja_{i,j}vol(G)=âˆ‘iâ€‹âˆ‘jâ€‹ai,jâ€‹. There are 3 important Lemmas:

    \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\rarr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\rarr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}\and \frac{\#(i,j)_{r\larr}}{|\mathcal D|_{r\larr}}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\\\frac{\#(i,j)}{|\mathcal D|}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{1}{2T}\sum_{r=1}^T\left(\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{d_i}{\text{vol(G)}}(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)\\\frac{\#(i,j)|D|}{\#(w),\#(c)}\stackrel{p}\rarr\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{2T}\left(\frac{1}{d_j}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{i,j}+\frac{1}{d_i}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf P^r)_{j,i}\right)

  • Putting all together we obtain DeepWalk with infinite length random walks converges to

    logâ¡(vol(G)k(1Tâˆ‘r=1T(Î”âˆ’1A)r)Î”âˆ’1)\log\left(\frac{\text{vol}(G)}{k}(\frac{1}{T}\sum_{r=1}^T(\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\mathbf A)^r)\mathbf\Delta^{-1}\right)log(kvol(G)â€‹(T1â€‹r=1âˆ‘Tâ€‹(Î”âˆ’1A)r)Î”âˆ’1)

    Notice that the internal sum reminds close to a random walk iteration as the power of matrix Î”âˆ’1A\mathbf \Delta^{-1}\mathbf AÎ”âˆ’1A encodes the probability of reaching nodes in rrr steps through random walking the graph. By factorizing such a similarity with SVD we can obtain the desired result that approximates the embeddings of a random-walk approach.

Graph Neural Network

abbr GNN

An architecture that allows nodes to propagate information to the neighbors in a non-linear manner. We have an attributed graph G=(V,E,X)G=(V,E,\mathbf X)G=(V,E,X) with matrix of node features XâˆˆRmÃ—n\mathbf X\in\mathbb R^{m\times n}XâˆˆRmÃ—n. (such a matrix encodes nodes attributes such as labels, profiles or characteristics)

The main ingredient of a GNN is the aggregation function that takes in input the features from the neighbors of a node iii and finds an embedding hi\mathbf h_ihiâ€‹.

Neighborhood Aggregation

Main idea: Generate node embeddings based on local neighborhoods of each node, using neural networks to represent the complex relationships of a graph.

Intuitively, think of the neighbors as a computational graph of a Neural Network.

The embeddings in the layer lll is an aggregation of the embeddings in layer lâˆ’1l-1lâˆ’1.

How to aggregate information across the layers? A simple approach: average neighbor information and apply a neural network.

The embeddings of the initial layer 000 are the attributes zi0=zi\mathbf z_i^0=\mathbf z_izi0â€‹=ziâ€‹. The lll-th layer embedding of iii is

zil=Ïƒ(Wlâˆ‘jâˆˆN(i)zjlâˆ’1âˆ£N(i)âˆ£+Blzilâˆ’1),âˆ€t>0\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{|N(i)|}+\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}),\forall t\gt0zilâ€‹=Ïƒ(Wlâ€‹jâˆˆN(i)âˆ‘â€‹âˆ£N(i)âˆ£zjlâˆ’1â€‹â€‹+Blâ€‹zilâˆ’1â€‹),âˆ€t>0

Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ is non-linear activation function. The sum is the average of each neighborâ€™s embeddings compute in layer lâˆ’1l-1lâˆ’1.

Loss function. W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B are the trainable weight matrices. After kkk-layers of neighborhood aggregation, we get output embeddings for each node. Loss function needs non-linear and differentiable.

We optimize the parameters of model through stochastic gradient descent SGD.

Rewrite model in matrix notation

Zl+1=Ïƒ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1l)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l+\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W^l_1)Zl+1=Ïƒ(ZlWl+A~ZlW1lâ€‹)

where A~=Î”âˆ’1/2AÎ”âˆ’1/2\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf {A\Delta}^{-1/2}A~=Î”âˆ’1/2AÎ”âˆ’1/2. To optimize the parameters, a cross-entropy loss function would work in a supervised setting w.r.t. nodeâ€™s labels.

An important properties of models: ability to share the parameters W,B\mathbf {W,B}W,B and allow for generalization to unseen nodes, edges or graphs.

Depend on loss function and embedding matrix, the GNN can learn node embeddings, graph embeddings or clusters.

Graph Convolutional Networks

abbr. GCN

A different neighbor aggragation

zil=Ïƒ(Wlâˆ‘jâˆˆN(i)âˆªizjlâˆ’1âˆ£N(i)âˆ£âˆ£N(j)âˆ£).\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma\left(\mathbf W_l\sum_{j\in N(i)\cup i}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{\sqrt{|N(i)||N(j)|}}\right).zilâ€‹=Ïƒââ›â€‹Wlâ€‹jâˆˆN(i)âˆªiâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£N(i)âˆ£âˆ£N(j)âˆ£â€‹zjlâˆ’1â€‹â€‹â ââ€‹.

The main idea is node with a large number of connections should be less important. There is no need for the bias term B\mathbf BB and the per-neighbor normalization.

Normalization empirically attains better results and better parameter sharing. We can efficiently compute the embeddings using sparse batch operations

Zl+1=Ïƒ(Î”âˆ’1/2A~Î”âˆ’1/2ZlWl)\mathbf Z^{l+1}=\sigma(\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\tilde{\mathbf A}\mathbf\Delta^{-1/2}\mathbf Z^l\mathbf W_l)Zl+1=Ïƒ(Î”âˆ’1/2A~Î”âˆ’1/2ZlWlâ€‹)

where A~=A+I\tilde{\mathbf A}=\mathbf A+\mathbf IA~=A+I and Î´\deltaÎ´ is the diagonal degree matrix. The time complexity to propagate the information is O(âˆ£Eâˆ£)\mathcal O(|E|)O(âˆ£Eâˆ£).

GraphSAGE

Instead of fixed aggregation, GraphSAGE use any differentiable function that maps set of vectors to a single vector. So, if we use a generalized aggregation, we get

zil=Ïƒ([Wlâ‹…AGG({zjlâˆ’1,âˆ€jâˆˆN(i)}),Blzilâˆ’1])\mathbf z_i^l=\sigma([\mathbf W_l\cdot AGG(\{\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\}),\mathbf B_l\mathbf z_i^{l-1}])zilâ€‹=Ïƒ([Wlâ€‹â‹…AGG({zjlâˆ’1â€‹,âˆ€jâˆˆN(i)}),Blâ€‹zilâˆ’1â€‹])

Concentrate self embedding of neighbor embedding. Also we use a generalized aggregation.

Some variants:

  • Mean. Take weighted average of neighbors:

    AGG=âˆ‘jâˆˆN(i)zjlâˆ’1N(i)AGG=\sum_{j\in N(i)}\frac{\mathbf z_j^{l-1}}{N(i)}AGG=jâˆˆN(i)âˆ‘â€‹N(i)zjlâˆ’1â€‹â€‹

  • Pool. Transform neighbor vectors and apply symmetric vector function:

    AGG=Î³({Qzjlâˆ’1,âˆ€jâˆˆN(i)})AGG=\gamma(\{\mathbf{Qz}_j^{l-1},\forall j\in N(i)\})AGG=Î³({Qzjlâˆ’1â€‹,âˆ€jâˆˆN(i)})

    where we take element-wise mean/max

  • LSTM. Apply LSTM to reshuffled neighbors Ï€(N(i))\pi(N(i))Ï€(N(i))

    AGG=LSTM([zjlâˆ’1,âˆ€jâˆˆÏ€(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([\mathbf z_j^{l-1},\forall j\in\pi(N(i))])AGG=LSTM([zjlâˆ’1â€‹,âˆ€jâˆˆÏ€(N(i))])
entry.summary:
GNN - graph neural networks

Intuition: how to propagate information over the neighbors in a non-linear manner.

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 9 Prophets, Secretaries and Martingales
entry.content:
First part of lecture notes on prophet inequality and secretary problem is by Anupam Gupta (CMU)

Prophet inequalities and Secretary problems are 2 classes of problem where online decision-making meets stochasticity: in the first set of problems the inputs are random variables, whereas in the second one the inputs are worst-case but revealed to the algorithm (aka decision maker) in random order.

Here are some results, proofs and techniques about them.

The Prophet Inequality

åœ¨ä¹‹å‰çš„ç®—æ³•åšå¼ˆè®ºè¯¾ä¸Šå­¦è¿‡ï¼Œå…·ä½“å¯ä»¥å‚è€ƒæˆ‘çš„å¯¹åº” è¯¾å ‚ç¬”è®°

nnn random variables X1,â‹¯â€‰,XnX_1,\cdots,X_nX1â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹. We know their distributions up-front, but not their realizations. The realizations are revealed one-by-one.

We want to give a strategy that, upon seeing the value XiX_iXiâ€‹ decides either to choose iii in which case we get reward XiX_iXiâ€‹ and the process stops. Or we can pass, in which case we move on to the next random variables, and are not allowed to come back to iii every again. We want to maximize our expected reward. If X_\max=\max\{X_1,X_2,\cdots,X_n\}, it is clear that our reward canâ€™t exceed \mathbb E[X_\max].

Theorem 1 by Krengel, Sucheston and Garling. There exists a strategy with expected reward \frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max].

Let Ï„\tauÏ„ be the median of the distribution of X_\max, i.e., \Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]=1/2.

Now the strategy is simple: pick the first XiX_iXiâ€‹ which exceeds Ï„\tauÏ„. Clearly, we will pick an item with probability exactly 121\over221â€‹, then notice that

\mathbb E[X_\max]\le\tau+\mathbb E[(X_\max-\tau)^+]\\\le\tau+\mathbb E[\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-\tau)^+].

Then for algorithm:

ALG\ge\tau\cdot\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]+\sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb E[(X_i-\tau)^+]\cdot\Pr[\bigwedge_{j\le i}(X_j\lt\tau)]\\\ge\tau\cdot\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]+\sum_{i=1}^n\mathbb E[(X_i-\tau)^+]\cdot\Pr[X_\max\lt\tau]

By letting \Pr[X_\max\lt\tau]=\Pr[X_\max\ge\tau]=1/2, we have

ALG\ge\frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max]

The proof is beautiful, but hard to generalize. What if we can choose kkk variables?

There are LP-based version of proof, which can be generalized:

Define pip_ipiâ€‹ as the probability that element XiX_iXiâ€‹ takes on the highest value. Hence âˆ‘ipi=1\sum_ip_i=1âˆ‘iâ€‹piâ€‹=1. Moreover, suppose Ï„i\tau_iÏ„iâ€‹ is s.t. Prâ¡[Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]=pi\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]=p_iPr[Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]=piâ€‹, i.e., the pip_ipiâ€‹-th percentile for XiX_iXiâ€‹. Define

vi(pi)=E[Xiâˆ£Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]v_i(p_i)=\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]viâ€‹(piâ€‹)=E[Xiâ€‹âˆ£Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]

as value of XiX_iXiâ€‹ conditioned on it lying in the top pip_ipiâ€‹-th percentile. Clearly, \mathbb E[X_\max]\le\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i.

A simpler weaker bound. Hereâ€™s a simple algorithm that gets value \frac{1}{4}\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i\ge\frac{1}{4}\mathbb E[X_\max].

If we havenâ€™t chosen an item among 1,â‹¯â€‰,iâˆ’11,\cdots,i-11,â‹¯,iâˆ’1, when looking at item iii, pass with probability half without even looking at XiX_iXiâ€‹, else accept it if Xiâ‰¥Ï„iX_i\ge\tau_iXiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹.

Definition: we â€œreachâ€ item iii if we have not picked an item before iii. The expected value of the algorithm is

ALGâ‰¥âˆ‘i=1nPrâ¡[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…12â‹…Prâ¡[Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]â‹…E[Xiâˆ£Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]=âˆ‘i=1nPrâ¡[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…12â‹…piâ‹…vi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]\cdot\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]\\=\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALGâ‰¥i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…21â€‹â‹…Pr[Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]â‹…E[Xiâ€‹âˆ£Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…21â€‹â‹…piâ€‹â‹…viâ€‹(piâ€‹)

Since we pick each item with probability 12pi\frac{1}{2}p_i21â€‹piâ€‹, the expected number of items we choose is half. So, by Markovâ€™s inequality, the probability we pick no item at all is at least half. Hence, the probability we reach item iii is at least one half too, the above expression is 14â‹…âˆ‘ivi(pi)â‹…pi\frac{1}{4}\cdot\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_i41â€‹â‹…âˆ‘iâ€‹viâ€‹(piâ€‹)â‹…piâ€‹ as claimed.

The bound of 2. To improve the algorithm, suppose we denote the probability of reaching item iii by rir_iriâ€‹ and suppose we reject item iii outright with probability 1âˆ’qi1-q_i1âˆ’qiâ€‹. Then inequality shows that

ALGâ‰¥âˆ‘i=1nriâ‹…qiâ‹…piâ‹…vi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^nr_i\cdot q_i\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALGâ‰¥i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹riâ€‹â‹…qiâ€‹â‹…piâ€‹â‹…viâ€‹(piâ€‹)

Above, we ensured that qi=ri=12q_i=r_i=\frac{1}{2}qiâ€‹=riâ€‹=21â€‹, and hence lost a factor of 14\frac{1}{4}41â€‹. But if we ensures that riâ‹…qi=1/2r_i\cdot q_i=1/2riâ€‹â‹…qiâ€‹=1/2, we would get the desired result of \frac{1}{2}\mathbb E[X_\max]. For the first item r1=1r_1=1r1â€‹=1 and hence we can set q1=12q_1=\frac{1}{2}q1â€‹=21â€‹.

For future items, since

ri+1=ri(1âˆ’qiâ‹…pi)r_{i+1}=r_i(1-q_i\cdot p_i)ri+1â€‹=riâ€‹(1âˆ’qiâ€‹â‹…piâ€‹)

we can just set qi+1=12ri+1q_{i+1}=\frac{1}{2r_{i+1}}qi+1â€‹=2ri+1â€‹1â€‹. A simple induction shows that ri+1â‰¥12r_{i+1}\ge\frac{1}{2}ri+1â€‹â‰¥21â€‹. Summing up this equation to get ri+1=r1âˆ’âˆ‘jâ‰¤ipi/2r_{i+1}=r_1-\sum_{j\le i}p_i/2ri+1â€‹=r1â€‹âˆ’âˆ‘jâ‰¤iâ€‹piâ€‹/2, so that qi+1âˆˆ[0,1]q_{i+1}\in[0,1]qi+1â€‹âˆˆ[0,1] and is well-defined.

The Computational Aspect

If the distribution of the random variable stream XiX_iXiâ€‹ is explicitly given, the proofs above immediately give us algorithms. But what if XiX_iXiâ€‹ are given via a black-box (we can only access via samples)?

The first proof merely relies on finding the median: finding an approximate median Ï„^\hat\tauÏ„^ s.t. \Pr[X_\max\lt\hat\tau]\in(\frac{1}{2}-\epsilon,\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon) gives us expected reward \frac{1}{2+\epsilon/2}\mathbb E[X_\max]. To do this, sample from X_\max O(\epsilon^{-2}\log\delta^{-1}) times and take Ï„^\hat\tauÏ„^ is an approximate median with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

For the second proof, there are 2 ways of making it algorithmic. Firstly, if the quantities are polynomially bounded, estimate pip_ipiâ€‹ and viv_iviâ€‹ by sampling. Alternatively, solve the convex program

maxâ¡{âˆ‘iyiâ‹…vi(yi)âˆ£âˆ‘iyi=1}\max\{\sum_iy_i\cdot v_i(y_i)|\sum_iy_i=1\}max{iâˆ‘â€‹yiâ€‹â‹…viâ€‹(yiâ€‹)âˆ£iâˆ‘â€‹yiâ€‹=1}

and use the yiy_iyiâ€‹â€™s from its solution in lieu of pip_ipiâ€‹â€™s in the algorithm above.

Since getting samples from the distributions may be expensive, there are method to get a constant fraction of \mathbb E[X_\max] via taking just one sample from each of the XiX_iXiâ€‹s.

Extensions: Picking Multiple Items

What if we are allowed to choose kkk variables from among the nnn?

If pip_ipiâ€‹ is the probability that XiX_iXiâ€‹ is among the top kkk values, we have

âˆ‘ipi=k.\sum_ip_i=k.iâˆ‘â€‹piâ€‹=k.

The upper bound on our quantity of interest remains essentially unchanged

E[sumÂ ofÂ topÂ kÂ r.v.s]â‰¤âˆ‘ivi(pi)â‹…pi\mathbb E[\text{sum of top }k\text{ r.v.s}]\le\sum_iv_i(p_i)\cdot p_iE[sumÂ ofÂ topÂ kÂ r.v.s]â‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹viâ€‹(piâ€‹)â‹…piâ€‹

What about an algorithm to get value 1/41/41/4 of the value in this inequality? Then same: reject each item outright with probability 1/21/21/2, else pick iii if Xiâ‰¥Ï„iX_i\ge\tau_iXiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹. Proof goes through unchanged.

Better

One can get within (1âˆ’1k+3)(1-\frac{1}{\sqrt{k+3}})(1âˆ’k+3â€‹1â€‹) of the value. For k=1k=1k=1, this matches 1/21/21/2. One can, however, get a fractor of 1âˆ’O(logâ¡kk)1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}})1âˆ’O(klogkâ€‹â€‹) using a simple concentration bound.

Suppose we reduce the rejection probability to Î´\deltaÎ´. Then the probability that we reach some item iii without having picked kkk items already is lower-bounded by the probability that we pick at most kkk elements in the entire process. Since we reject items with probability Î´\deltaÎ´, the expected number of elements we pick is (1âˆ’Î´)k(1-\delta)k(1âˆ’Î´)k.

Hence, the probability that we pick less than kkk items is at least 1âˆ’eâˆ’Î˜(Î´2k)1-e^{-\Theta(\delta^2k)}1âˆ’eâˆ’Î˜(Î´2k), by a Hoeffding bound for sums of independent random variables. Now setting Î´=O(logâ¡kk)\delta=O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}})Î´=O(klogkâ€‹â€‹) ensures that the probability of reaching each item is at least (1âˆ’1/k)(1-1/k)(1âˆ’1/k), and a argument similar to that in Proof shows that

ALGâ‰¥âˆ‘i=1nPrâ¡[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…Prâ¡[notÂ rejectÂ itemÂ i]â‹…Prâ¡[Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]â‹…E[Xiâˆ£Xiâ‰¥Ï„i]=âˆ‘i=1n(1âˆ’1/k)â‹…(1âˆ’O(logâ¡kk))â‹…piâ‹…vi(pi)ALG\ge\sum_{i=1}^n\Pr[\text{reach item }i]\cdot\Pr[\text{not reject item }i]\cdot\Pr[X_i\ge\tau_i]\cdot\mathbb E[X_i|X_i\ge\tau_i]\\=\sum_{i=1}^n(1-1/k)\cdot(1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}}))\cdot p_i\cdot v_i(p_i)ALGâ‰¥i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr[reachÂ itemÂ i]â‹…Pr[notÂ rejectÂ itemÂ i]â‹…Pr[Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]â‹…E[Xiâ€‹âˆ£Xiâ€‹â‰¥Ï„iâ€‹]=i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹(1âˆ’1/k)â‹…(1âˆ’O(klogkâ€‹â€‹))â‹…piâ€‹â‹…viâ€‹(piâ€‹)

which gives the claimed bound of (1âˆ’O(logâ¡kk))(1-O(\sqrt{\frac{\log k}{k}}))(1âˆ’O(klogkâ€‹â€‹)).

Secretary Problems

nnn items, each has some intrinsic non-negative value.

Assume the values are distinct, but we know nothing about their ranges.

We only know nnn.

The item are presented one by one. Upon seeing an item, we can either pick it or we can pass. The goal is to maximize the probability of picking the item with the highest value.

If an adversary chooses the order in which the items are presented, every deterministic strategy must fail.

â“Secretary problem: what if the items are presented in uniformly random order? For this setting, it seems surprising that one can prove the following theorem:

Theorem 2.1. There is a strategy to pick the best item with probability at least 1e\frac{1}{e}e1â€‹.

A simple algorithm and proof showing probability of 14\frac{1}{4}41â€‹: ignore the first n/2n/2n/2 items, and then pick the next item that is better than all the ones seen so far. Note that this algorithm succeeds if the best item is in the second half of the items (happens with probability 1/21/21/2). Hence 1/41/41/4. Rejecting the first half of the items is not optimal, and there are other cases where the algorithm succeeds that this simple analysis does not account for.

First, the algorithm should never pick an element that is not the best so far. Moreover, if we define

f(i)=Prâ¡[ithÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ bestâˆ£ithÂ isÂ bestÂ soÂ far]=Prâ¡[ithÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ best]Prâ¡[ithÂ isÂ bestÂ soÂ far]=1/n1/i=ing(i)=Prâ¡[pickingÂ globalÂ bestÂ usingÂ optimalÂ strategyÂ fromÂ itemÂ iÂ onwards]f(i)=\Pr[i^{th}\text{ item is global best}|i^{th}\text{ is best so far}]\\=\frac{\Pr[i^{th}\text{ item is global best}]}{\Pr[i^{th}\text{ is best so far}]}=\frac{1/n}{1/i}=\frac{i}{n}\\g(i)=\Pr[\text{picking global best using optimal strategy from item i onwards}]f(i)=Pr[ithÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ bestâˆ£ithÂ isÂ bestÂ soÂ far]=Pr[ithÂ isÂ bestÂ soÂ far]Pr[ithÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ best]â€‹=1/i1/nâ€‹=niâ€‹g(i)=Pr[pickingÂ globalÂ bestÂ usingÂ optimalÂ strategyÂ fromÂ itemÂ iÂ onwards]

then g(i)g(i)g(i) is a non-increasing and f(i)f(i)f(i) is increasing.

Any optimal strategy should pass at times iii where f(i)<g(i+1)f(i)\lt g(i+1)f(i)<g(i+1) and pick at other times if we see an element that is best so far. i.e., a strategy of the type used in the simple proof of 1/41/41/4 is optimal.

So if we reject the first Ï„\tauÏ„ items, then the probability we succeed in picking the global best is

âˆ‘t=Ï„+1nPrâ¡[tthÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ best]â‹…Prâ¡[bestÂ ofÂ firstÂ tâˆ’1Â itemsÂ inÂ firstÂ Ï„Â positions]=âˆ‘t=Ï„+1n1nâ‹…Ï„tâˆ’1=Ï„n(Hnâˆ’1âˆ’HÏ„âˆ’1).\sum_{t=\tau+1}^n\Pr[t^{th}\text{ item is global best}]\cdot\Pr[\text{best of first }t-1\text{ items in first }\tau\text{ positions}]\\=\sum_{t=\tau+1}^n\frac{1}{n}\cdot\frac{\tau}{t-1}=\frac{\tau}{n}(H_{n-1}-H_{\tau-1}).t=Ï„+1âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr[tthÂ itemÂ isÂ globalÂ best]â‹…Pr[bestÂ ofÂ firstÂ tâˆ’1Â itemsÂ inÂ firstÂ Ï„Â positions]=t=Ï„+1âˆ‘nâ€‹n1â€‹â‹…tâˆ’1Ï„â€‹=nÏ„â€‹(Hnâˆ’1â€‹âˆ’HÏ„âˆ’1â€‹).

This is g(Ï„+1)g(\tau+1)g(Ï„+1). So the first position where f(Ï„)=Ï„/nâ‰¥g(Ï„+1)f(\tau)=\tau/n\ge g(\tau+1)f(Ï„)=Ï„/nâ‰¥g(Ï„+1) is given by the smallest Ï„\tauÏ„ s.t. 1â‰¥Hnâˆ’1âˆ’HÏ„âˆ’11\ge H_{n-1}-H_{\tau-1}1â‰¥Hnâˆ’1â€‹âˆ’HÏ„âˆ’1â€‹, i.e., Ï„â‰ˆn/e\tau\approx n/eÏ„â‰ˆn/e for large nnn, hence g(Ï„+1)â‰ˆ1/eg(\tau+1)\approx1/eg(Ï„+1)â‰ˆ1/e.

There is an alternate proof that uses a convex-programming. We will write down an LP that captures some properties of any feasible solution, optimize this LP and show a strategy whose success probability is comparable to the objective of this LP.

Extension: Game-Theoretic Issues

In the optimal strategy, we donâ€™t pick any items in the first n/en/en/e timesteps, and then we pick items with quite varying probabilities.

Suppose we insist that for each position iii, the probability of picking the item at position iii is the same.

Letâ€™s fix any such strategy, and write an LP capturing the success probbailities of this strategy with uniformity condition as a constraint. Suppose pâ‰¤1/np\le1/npâ‰¤1/n is this uniform probability. Again, let qiq_iqiâ€‹ be the probability of picking an item at position iii, conditioned on it being the best so far. Extension: Multiple Items

Suppose we want kkk items, maximizing the expected sum of these kkk values.

Second part of lecture notes on martingales is by Elias Koutsoupias (Oxford)

Martingales

ä¸­æ–‡ç¿»è¯‘ï¼šâ€é…â€œï¼Œä¹‹å‰ä»æ¥æ²¡å¬è¯´è¿‡ã€‚

Chernoff bounds cannot be used for sums of dependent variables.

If the dependency of particular type, the Azuma-Hoeffding inequality provides a general concentration bound.

Definition of martingale: A martingale is a sequence of random variables X0,X1,â‹¯X_0,X_1,\cdotsX0â€‹,X1â€‹,â‹¯ of bounded expectation s.t. for every iâ‰¥0i\ge0iâ‰¥0,

E[Xi+1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]=Xi.\mathbb E[X_{i+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_i]=X_i.E[Xi+1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]=Xiâ€‹.

More generally, a sequence of random variables Z0,Z1,â‹¯Z_0,Z_1,\cdotsZ0â€‹,Z1â€‹,â‹¯ is a martingale w.r.t. the sequence X0,X1,â‹¯X_0,X_1,\cdotsX0â€‹,X1â€‹,â‹¯ if for all n>0n\gt0n>0 the following conditions hold:

  • ZnZ_nZnâ€‹ is a function of X0,â‹¯â€‰,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹
  • E[âˆ£Znâˆ£]â‰¤âˆ\mathbb E[|Z_n|]\le\inftyE[âˆ£Znâ€‹âˆ£]â‰¤âˆ
  • E[Zn+1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xn]=Zn\mathbb E[Z_{n+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_n]=Z_nE[Zn+1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹]=Znâ€‹

Here are some example of martingales.

Gamblerâ€™s Fortune

A gambler plays a sequence of fair games. Let XiX_iXiâ€‹ be the amount that the gamblerâ€™s total winnings immediately after the iii-th game. Since the games are fair, E[Xi]=0\mathbb E[X_i]=0E[Xiâ€‹]=0 and E[Zi+1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]=Zi+E[Xi+1]=Zi\mathbb E[Z_{i+1}|X_0,\cdots, X_i]=Z_i+\mathbb E[X_{i+1}]=Z_iE[Zi+1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]=Ziâ€‹+E[Xi+1â€‹]=Ziâ€‹, which shows that very finite sequence Z0,Z1,â‹¯â€‰,ZnZ_0,Z_1,\cdots,Z_nZ0â€‹,Z1â€‹,â‹¯,Znâ€‹ is a martingale. This is a generalization of the simple random walk on a line. The gambler can use the past outcomes and any algorithm to calculate the amount of the next bet.

Balls and Bins

Suppose that we throw mmm balls into nnn bins independently and uniformly at random.

Consider the expected number of empty bins. Let XiX_iXiâ€‹ be the random variable representing the bin into which the iii-th ball falls. Let YYY be a random variable representing the number of empty bins. Then the sequence of random variables

Zi=E[Yâˆ£X1,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]Z_i=\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i]Ziâ€‹=E[Yâˆ£X1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]

is a martingale. Clearly ZiZ_iZiâ€‹ is a function of the X1,â‹¯â€‰,XiX_1,\cdots,X_iX1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹â€™s and has bounded expectation. Furthermore

E[Zi+1âˆ£X1,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]=E[E[Yâˆ£X1,â‹¯â€‰,Xi,Xi+1]âˆ£X1,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]=E[Yâˆ£X1,â‹¯â€‰,Xi]=Zi\mathbb E[Z_{i+1}|X_1,\cdots,X_i]=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i,X_{i+1}]|X_1,\cdots,X_i]\\=\mathbb E[Y|X_1,\cdots,X_i]=Z_iE[Zi+1â€‹âˆ£X1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]=E[E[Yâˆ£X1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹,Xi+1â€‹]âˆ£X1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]=E[Yâˆ£X1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹]=Ziâ€‹

We can view ZiZ_iZiâ€‹ as an estimate of YYY after having observed the outcomes X1,â‹¯â€‰,XiX_1,\cdots,X_iX1â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâ€‹. At the beginning Z0Z_0Z0â€‹ is a crude estimate, simply the expectation of YYY. As we add more balls to the bins. ZiZ_iZiâ€‹â€™s give improved estimates of YYY, and at the end we get the exact value Zm=YZ_m=YZmâ€‹=Y.

Doob Martingales

The balls and bins is a typical doob martingale. Doob martingales are processes in which we obtain a sequence of improved estimates of the value of a random variable as information about it is revealed progressively. More precisely, suppose YYY is a r.v. that is a function of random variables X0,X1,â‹¯X_0,X_1,\cdotsX0â€‹,X1â€‹,â‹¯. As we observe the sequence of random variables X0,â‹¯â€‰,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹, we improve our estimates of YYY. The sequence of the mean estimates

Zt=E[Yâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xt]Z_t=\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t]Ztâ€‹=E[Yâˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xtâ€‹]

form a martingale w.r.t. the sequence X0,â‹¯â€‰,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹ (provided that ZtZ_tZtâ€‹â€™s bounded). Indeed, when we argued that the balls and bins process is a martingale, we used no property of the experiment, therefore the following holds in general

E[Zt+1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xt]=E[E[Yâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xt,Xt+1]âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xt]=E[Yâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xt]=Zt\mathbb E[Z_{t+1}|X_0,\cdots,X_t]\\=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t,X_{t+1}]|X_0,\cdots,X_t]\\=\mathbb E[Y|X_0,\cdots,X_t]=Z_tE[Zt+1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xtâ€‹]=E[E[Yâˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xtâ€‹,Xt+1â€‹]âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xtâ€‹]=E[Yâˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xtâ€‹]=Ztâ€‹

Azuma-Hoeffding Inequality

Let X0,â‹¯â€‰,XnX_0,\cdots,X_nX0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâ€‹ be a martingale s.t. âˆ£Xiâˆ’Xiâˆ’1âˆ£â‰¤ci|X_i-X_{i-1}|\le c_iâˆ£Xiâ€‹âˆ’Xiâˆ’1â€‹âˆ£â‰¤ciâ€‹.

Then for any Î»>0\lambda\gt0Î»>0,

P(Xnâˆ’X0â‰¥Î»)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Î»22âˆ‘i=1nci2),\mathbb P(X_n-X_0\ge\lambda)\le\exp(-\frac{\lambda^2}{2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2}),P(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹â‰¥Î»)â‰¤exp(âˆ’2âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ci2â€‹Î»2â€‹),

and

P(Xnâˆ’X0â‰¤âˆ’Î»)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Î»22âˆ‘i=1nci2).\mathbb P(X_n-X_0\le-\lambda)\le\exp(-\frac{\lambda^2}{2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2}).P(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹â‰¤âˆ’Î»)â‰¤exp(âˆ’2âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ci2â€‹Î»2â€‹).

Proof of the first inequality, (similar proof for second inequality):

By applying Markovâ€™s inequality to an appropriate random variable and it is similar to the proof of Chernoffâ€™s bounds.

We use the variables Yi=Xiâˆ’Xiâˆ’1Y_i=X_i-X_{i-1}Yiâ€‹=Xiâ€‹âˆ’Xiâˆ’1â€‹. The step of the proof:

P(expâ¡(t(Xnâˆ’X0))â‰¥expâ¡(tÎ»))â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’tÎ»)E[expâ¡(t(Xnâˆ’X0))].\mathbb P(\exp(t(X_n-X_0))\ge\exp(t\lambda))\le\exp(-t\lambda)\mathbb E[\exp(t(X_n-X_0))].P(exp(t(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹))â‰¥exp(tÎ»))â‰¤exp(âˆ’tÎ»)E[exp(t(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹))].

Then focus on E[expâ¡(t(Xnâˆ’X0))]\mathbb E[\exp(t(X_n-X_0))]E[exp(t(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹))], which can be replaced by YiY_iYiâ€‹â€™s

by telescoping, Xnâˆ’X0âˆ‘i=1n(Xiâˆ’Xiâˆ’1)=âˆ‘i=1nYiX_n-X_0\sum_{i=1}^n(X_i-X_{i-1})=\sum_{i=1}^nY_iXnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹(Xiâ€‹âˆ’Xiâˆ’1â€‹)=âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹Yiâ€‹.

  1. We canâ€™t use E[Y1Y2]=E[Y1]E[Y2]\mathbb E[Y_1Y_2]=\mathbb E[Y_1]\mathbb E[Y_2]E[Y1â€‹Y2â€‹]=E[Y1â€‹]E[Y2â€‹] since YiY_iYiâ€‹s are not independent. Consider the conditional expectation.

E[âˆi=1nexpâ¡(tYi)âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1]=(âˆi=1nâˆ’1expâ¡(tYi))E[expâ¡(tYn)âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1]\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]\\=(\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i))\mathbb E[\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]E[i=1âˆnâ€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹]=(i=1âˆnâˆ’1â€‹exp(tYiâ€‹))E[exp(tYnâ€‹)âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹]

because for fixed X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹, all but the last factor in the product are constant and can be moved out.

Then find an upper bound on E[expâ¡(tYn)âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1]\mathbb E[\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]E[exp(tYnâ€‹)âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹].

  • Observe that E[Yiâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]=0\mathbb E[Y_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]=0E[Yiâ€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]=0 by martingale property.

    E[Yiâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]=E[Xiâˆ’Xiâˆ’1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]=E[Xiâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]âˆ’E[Xiâˆ’1âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]=Xiâˆ’1âˆ’Xiâˆ’1=0\mathbb E[Y_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\mathbb E[X_i-X_{i-1}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\mathbb E[X_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]-\mathbb E[X_{i-1}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=X_{i-1}-X_{i-1}=0E[Yiâ€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]=E[Xiâ€‹âˆ’Xiâˆ’1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]=E[Xiâ€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]âˆ’E[Xiâˆ’1â€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]=Xiâˆ’1â€‹âˆ’Xiâˆ’1â€‹=0

  • Then by the condition âˆ£Yiâˆ£â‰¤ci|Y_i|\le c_iâˆ£Yiâ€‹âˆ£â‰¤ciâ€‹,

    expâ¡(tYi)â‰¤Î²i+Î³iYi\exp(tY_i)\le\beta_i+\gamma_iY_iexp(tYiâ€‹)â‰¤Î²iâ€‹+Î³iâ€‹Yiâ€‹

    for Î²i=(etci+eâˆ’tci)/2â‰¤expâ¡((tci)2/2)\beta_i=(e^{tc_i}+e^{-tc_i})/2\le\exp((tc_i)^2/2)Î²iâ€‹=(etciâ€‹+eâˆ’tciâ€‹)/2â‰¤exp((tciâ€‹)2/2), Î³i=(etci+eâˆ’tci)/(2ci)\gamma_i=(e^{tc_i}+e^{-tc_i})/(2c_i)Î³iâ€‹=(etciâ€‹+eâˆ’tciâ€‹)/(2ciâ€‹). Then rewrite YiY_iYiâ€‹ as Yi=rci+(1âˆ’r)(âˆ’ci)Y_i=rc_i+(1-r)(-c_i)Yiâ€‹=rciâ€‹+(1âˆ’r)(âˆ’ciâ€‹), where r=1+Yi/ci2âˆˆ[0,1]r=\frac{1+Y_i/c_i}{2}\in[0,1]r=21+Yiâ€‹/ciâ€‹â€‹âˆˆ[0,1], then use the convexity of etxe^{tx}etx to get

    etYiâ‰¤retci+(1âˆ’r)eâˆ’tci=Î²i+Î³iYi.e^{tY_i}\le re^{tc_i}+(1-r)e^{-tc_i}\\=\beta_i+\gamma_iY_i.etYiâ€‹â‰¤retciâ€‹+(1âˆ’r)eâˆ’tciâ€‹=Î²iâ€‹+Î³iâ€‹Yiâ€‹.

  • Combine the above to get

    E[etYiâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]â‰¤E[Î²i+Î³iYiâˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xiâˆ’1]=Î²iâ‰¤expâ¡((tci)2/2).\mathbb E[e^{tY_i}|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\le\mathbb E[\beta_i+\gamma_iY_i|X_0,\cdots,X_{i-1}]\\=\beta_i\le\exp((tc_i)^2/2).E[etYiâ€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]â‰¤E[Î²iâ€‹+Î³iâ€‹Yiâ€‹âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xiâˆ’1â€‹]=Î²iâ€‹â‰¤exp((tciâ€‹)2/2).

It follows that

E[âˆi=1nexpâ¡(tYi)]=E[âˆi=1nâˆ’1expâ¡(tYi)Ã—expâ¡(tYn)âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1]â‰¤E[âˆi=1nâˆ’1expâ¡(tYi)]expâ¡((tcn)2/2).\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]=\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)\times\exp(tY_n)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]\\\le\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)]\exp((tc_n)^2/2).E[i=1âˆnâ€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)]=E[i=1âˆnâˆ’1â€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)Ã—exp(tYnâ€‹)âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹]â‰¤E[i=1âˆnâˆ’1â€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)]exp((tcnâ€‹)2/2).

  1. Then take expectations on both sides to get rid of the conditional expectation:

E[âˆi=1nexpâ¡(tYi)]=E[E[âˆi=1nâˆ’1expâ¡(tYi)âˆ£X0,â‹¯â€‰,Xnâˆ’1]]â‰¤E[âˆi=1nâˆ’1expâ¡(tYi)]expâ¡((tcn)2/2).\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]=\mathbb E[\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)|X_0,\cdots,X_{n-1}]]\\\le\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^{n-1}\exp(tY_i)]\exp((tc_n)^2/2).E[i=1âˆnâ€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)]=E[E[i=1âˆnâˆ’1â€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)âˆ£X0â€‹,â‹¯,Xnâˆ’1â€‹]]â‰¤E[i=1âˆnâˆ’1â€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)]exp((tcnâ€‹)2/2).

  1. Then use same standard techniques
  • By induction: E[âˆi=1nexpâ¡(tYi)]â‰¤âˆi=1nexpâ¡((tci2)/2)=expâ¡(t2âˆ‘i=1nci2/2)\mathbb E[\prod_{i=1}^n\exp(tY_i)]\le\prod_{i=1}^n\exp((tc_i^2)/2)=\exp(t^2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2/2)E[âˆi=1nâ€‹exp(tYiâ€‹)]â‰¤âˆi=1nâ€‹exp((tci2â€‹)/2)=exp(t2âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ci2â€‹/2)
  • Therefore P(expâ¡(t(Xnâˆ’X0))â‰¥expâ¡(Î»t))â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Î»t)expâ¡(t2âˆ‘i=1nci2/2)\mathbb P(\exp(t(X_n-X_0))\ge\exp(\lambda t))\le\exp(-\lambda t)\exp(t^2\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2/2)P(exp(t(Xnâ€‹âˆ’X0â€‹))â‰¥exp(Î»t))â‰¤exp(âˆ’Î»t)exp(t2âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ci2â€‹/2)
  • Set t=Î»/âˆ‘i=1nci2t=\lambda/\sum_{i=1}^nc_i^2t=Î»/âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹ci2â€‹ to minimize the above expression and get the bound of the theorem.

Apply AH Bounds on Gamblerâ€™s Fortune

A gambler plays a sequence of fair games. We have seen that if ZiZ_iZiâ€‹ denotes the gamblerâ€™s total winnings immediately after the iii-th game, the sequence Z0,â‹¯â€‰,ZnZ_0,\cdots,Z_nZ0â€‹,â‹¯,Znâ€‹ is a martingale. Suppose that the gambler has a very sophisticated algorithm to decide the amount that he bets every day that takes into account past bets and outcomes. Since the games are fair, the expected gain ZnZ_nZnâ€‹ is zero.

Winning is not concentrated around the mean value in general.

For example, the case that gambler puts higher and higher bets. Suppose now that there is a bound on the size of bets, By AH inequality, the final winnings are concentrated with high probability in [âˆ’k,k][-k,k][âˆ’k,k] where k=O(nlogâ¡n)k=O(\sqrt{n\log n})k=O(nlognâ€‹).

Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren,

mit groÃŸen Interesse habe ich Ihren Artikel â€Wissenschaftler fordern Mittagsschlaf im BÃ¼roâ€œ gelesen.

Ich bin der Meinung, dass das Schlafen am Arbeitsplatz sehr wichtig ist, denn dadurch kÃ¶nnen die Mitarbeiter ihre Leistung æ•ˆç‡ wiedererlangen æ¢å¤ und fit an die Arbeit zurÃ¼ckkehren å›å½’.

Der Mittagsschlaf im BÃ¼ro sollte nicht nur erlaubt, sondern auch gefÃ¶rdert werden.

Im Folgenden mÃ¶chte ich meine Meinung dazu einmal erlÃ¤utern è§£é‡Š. Laut zahlreichen Studien ist der Mittagsschlaf vorteilhaft æœ‰ç›Šçš„, wie folgende Beispiele zeigen/verdeutlichen:

Schon nach 20 Minuten Mittagsruhe zeigen sich positive Auswirkungen auf den KÃ¶rper: Der Blutdruck sinkt, die Muskeln entspannen sich, Stresshormone werden abgebaut.

AuÃŸerdem wurde auch bewiesen, dass er zu wenig schlÃ¤ft, laut Medizinern, hÃ¤ufiger Fehler bei der Arbeit macht.

Deswegen sollte der Mittagsschlaf in Deutschland eigentlich Ã¼blich sein. Aber fÃ¼r die meisten kommt ein Mittagsschlaf Ã¼berhaupt nicht in Frage ä¸åœ¨è€ƒè™‘èŒƒå›´å†…, weil sie furchten, als faul zu gelten.

Es ist tatsÃ¤chlich schwer den Minischlaf oder Kurzschlaf in Betrieben einzufÃ¼hren é‡‡ç”¨. In Deutschland hat man im Durchschnitt 30 Minuten Mittagspause. Gerade lang genug fÃ¼r das Mittagessen. Nach dem Essen geht es direkt wieder an die Arbeit. Doch so kurz nach dem Essen, fÃ¤llt sich schwer auf seine Arbeit zu konzentrieren.

Wenn es mÃ¶glich wÃ¤re, wÃ¼rde ich auf jeden Fall einen Mittagsschlaf machen.â€™

AbschlieÃŸend mÃ¶chte ich nochmals betonen, dass sich Mittagsschlaf positiv auf die LeistungsfÃ¤higkeit auswirkt und gesund ist. In Unternehmen sollte der Mittagsschlaf eingesetzt und gleichzeitig gefÃ¶rdert werden.

entry.title: Fair Division 6 Computing EF1 + PO
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate methods for computing allocations satisfying both EF1 and PO.

Activities: Review the paper Finding Fair and Efficient Allocations.

Caragiannis et al has established the result: for additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 + PO by maximizing Nash Social Welfare.

However, computing MNW is NP-Hard.

This paper:

  1. develop a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm for finding EF1 + PO. When valuations are bounded, the algorithm is polynomial time.
  2. For additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally Pareto Efficient.
  3. The algorithm provides a polynomial time 1.451.451.45-approximation to the Nash social welfare objective.
  4. The algorithm is completely combinatorial, and relies on constructing integral Fisher market wherein specific equilibria are not only efficient, but also fair.

~~This paper is very difficult and I felt suffocated while reading it.~~ğŸ¤¡ğŸ¤¡ğŸ¤¡

Introduction

Caragiannis showed by maximizing Nash Welfare, the geometric mean of the agentsâ€™ valuations is both fair (EF1) and Pareto efficient. However, maximizing the Nash welfare is an NP-hard problem (more accurately, APX-hard)

This paper provides a pseudo-polynomial time algorithm for finding an EF1 and Pareto Optimal allocation of indivisible goods under additive valuations.

In particular, if the valuations are scaled, the algorithm finds such an allocation in polynomial time.

Maximizing Nash welfare remains APX-hard even for bounded valuations.

Related problem: approximation algorithm for Nash welfare maximization. But approximating Maximal Nash welfare is not guaranteed to be EF1 or Pareto optimal.

This algorithm provides a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation to the Maximal Nash welfare problem. SOTA! It is also guaranteed to return a fair and efficient outcome.

Contributions

  1. Pseudo-polynomial for unscaled valuation and polynomial for scaled valuation. Computing EF1 + PO allocations. This algorithm can find an approximate EF1 and approximate PO allocation without scaled valuations.

  2. Stronger existence results. For additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally Pareto efficient.

    There exists a non-deterministic polynomial time algorithm for finding EF1 + PO.

    Whereas even verifying whether an arbitrary allocation is PO is known to be co-NP-complete.

  3. Polynomial time 1.451.451.45-approximation for the Nash social welfare maximization.

    Interesting byproduct: under same valuations, EF1 allocation provides a 1.451.451.45-approximation to the MNW.

Techniques

Fisher market along with an underlying equilibrium which is integral and EF1.

Start with a Pareto Optimal allocation, then iteratively modify the allocation by exchanging goods between the agents. The goal of the exchange step is to move toward a fair allocation. Stop when the equilibrium of the market satisfies price envy-freeness up to one good.

First the algorithm works with an integral Fisher market at every step, breaking away from the standard relax-and-round paradigm where a fractional market equilibrium is first computed followed by round step. Second, the algorithm uses the notion of price envy-freeness up to one good as a measure of balanced spending in the Fisher market. The notion is novel.

Preliminaries

The Fair Division Model

Problem Instance

Omitted!!!

Valuations are non-negative, additive.

For single item jjj, denote iiiâ€™s valuation for it as vi,j=vi({j})v_{i,j}=v_i(\{j\})vi,jâ€‹=viâ€‹({j})

Denote v_\max=\max_{i\in[n],j\in[m]}v_i(j)=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Allocation

Allocation: Omitted!!!

Fractional allocation: For all agents, no more than one unit of each good is allocated:

âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]xi,jâ‰¤1\sum_{i\in[n]}x_{i,j}\le1iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘â€‹xi,jâ€‹â‰¤1

Fairness Notions

EF, EF1

Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-EF1: for every pair of agent i,kâˆˆ[n]i,k\in[n]i,kâˆˆ[n], there exists a good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹ s.t.

(1+Ïµ)vi(xi)â‰¥vi(xkâ•²{j})(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbb x_i)\ge v_i(\mathbb x_k\diagdown\{j\})(1+Ïµ)viâ€‹(xiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(xkâ€‹â•²{j})

Nash social welfare

NSW(x)=(âˆiâˆˆ[n]vi(xi))1/nNSW(\mathbf x)=(\prod_{i\in[n]}v_i(\mathbf x_i))^{1/n}NSW(x)=(iâˆˆ[n]âˆâ€‹viâ€‹(xiâ€‹))1/n

It is okay to ignore the 1/n1/n1/n power.

xâˆ—âˆˆargâ¡maxâ¡xâˆˆXNSW(x)\mathbf x^*\in\arg\max_{\mathbf x\in\mathcal X}NSW(\mathbf x)xâˆ—âˆˆargmaxxâˆˆXâ€‹NSW(x)

Efficiency Notions

Pareto Efficiency.

x\mathbf xx is Pareto dominated by another allocation y\mathbf yy if vk(yk)â‰¥vk(xk)v_k(\mathbf y_k)\ge v_k(\mathbf x_k)vkâ€‹(ykâ€‹)â‰¥vkâ€‹(xkâ€‹) for every agent kâˆˆ[n]k\in[n]kâˆˆ[n], and some of them is >\gt>.

An allocation is said to be Pareto efficient or Pareto optimal if it is not Pareto dominated by any other allocation. Similarly, x\mathbf xx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-PO if it is not Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-PO dominated by any other allocation (vk(yk)â‰¥(1+Ïµ)vk(xk)v_k(\mathbf y_k)\ge(1+\epsilon)v_k(\mathbf x_k)vkâ€‹(ykâ€‹)â‰¥(1+Ïµ)vkâ€‹(xkâ€‹), for some kkk the inequalities are strict).

Fractional Pareto Efficiency. If it is not Pareto dominated by any fractional allocation.

fractionally PO â‡’\Rarrâ‡’ PO, but PO â‡’Ì¸\not\Rarrî€ â‡’ fractionally PO.

Main Results

Algorithm computes EF1 + PO

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 1.

Given any fair division instance I\mathcal II with additive valuations, an allocation that is EF1 and PO can be found in O(poly(m,n,vmaxâ¡))\mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,v_{\max}))O(poly(m,n,vmaxâ€‹)) time, where v_\max=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Remark: If v_\max is polynomial bounded by f(m,n)f(m,n)f(m,n), the EF1 + PO can be computed in polynomial time.

If we relax the fairness and efficiency requirements to approximate versions, then the algorithm is guaranteed to run in polynomial time.

Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-EF1 + Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-PO in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max))

Existence for EF1 and fractionally PO

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. Given any fair division instance with additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fractionally PO (fPO)

Remark: ğŸ˜­ I donâ€™t understand. What is TFNP (Total Function Nondeterministic Polynomial)?

A binary relation P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) is in TFNP if and only if there is a deterministic polynomial time algorithm that can determine whether P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) holds given both xxx and yyy, and for every xxx, there exists a yyy which is at most polynomially longer than xxx such that P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) holds.

Approximation algorithm for Nash social welfare

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 3. For additive valuations, there exists a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for the Nash social welfare maximization problem.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 1. Given a fair division instance with identical and additive valuations, any Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-EF1 allocations provides a e(1+Ïµ)ee^{(1+\epsilon)e}e(1+Ïµ)e-approximation to Nash social welfare.

The Algorithm

Market Terminology

Fisher Market

A fundamental model in the economics of resource allocation.

A set of buyers enter the market with pre-specified budgets and use it to buy goods that provide maximum utility per unit of money spent.

[n][n][n] buyers, [m][m][m] divisible goods, valuation profile V\mathcal VV.

Each buyer iâˆˆ[n]i\in[n]iâˆˆ[n] has an initial endowment/budget ei>0e_i\gt0eiâ€‹>0. The endowment is only used for buying goods. Endowment vector e\mathbf ee.

A market instance âŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V,\mathbf e\rangleâŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ©

A market outcome is given by the pair âŸ¨x,pâŸ©\langle\mathbf x,\mathbf p\rangleâŸ¨x,pâŸ©, where the allocation vector x\mathbf xx is a fractional allocation of the mmm goods, and the price vector p\mathbf pp associates a price pjâ‰¥0p_j\ge0pjâ€‹â‰¥0 with each good jâˆˆ[m]j\in[m]jâˆˆ[m].

The spending of buyer iii under the market outcome âŸ¨x,pâŸ©\langle\mathbf x,\mathbf p\rangleâŸ¨x,pâŸ© is given by p(xi)=âˆ‘j=1mxi,jpj\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)=\sum_{j=1}^mx_{i,j}p_jp(xiâ€‹)=âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹xi,jâ€‹pjâ€‹.

The valuation derived by iii under the market outcome âŸ¨x,pâŸ©\langle\mathbf x,\mathbf p\rangleâŸ¨x,pâŸ© is given by vi(xi)=âˆ‘j=1mxi,jvi,jv_i(\mathbf x_i)=\sum_{j=1}^mx_{i,j}v_{i,j}viâ€‹(xiâ€‹)=âˆ‘j=1mâ€‹xi,jâ€‹vi,jâ€‹.

Given a price vector p\mathbf pp, define the bang per buck ratio of buyer iii for good jjj as

Î±i,j=vi,j/pj\alpha_{i,j}=v_{i,j}/p_jÎ±i,jâ€‹=vi,jâ€‹/pjâ€‹

æ˜¾ç„¶è¿™ä¸ªæ€§ä»·æ¯”è¶Šé«˜ï¼Œiii å°±è¶Šé«˜å…´ã€‚

The maximum bang per buck ratio is Î±i=maxâ¡jÎ±i,j\alpha_i=\max_j\alpha_{i,j}Î±iâ€‹=maxjâ€‹Î±i,jâ€‹.

Let MBBi={jâˆˆ[m]:vi,j/pj=Î±i}MBB_i=\{j\in[m]:v_{i,j}/p_j=\alpha_i\}MBBiâ€‹={jâˆˆ[m]:vi,jâ€‹/pjâ€‹=Î±iâ€‹} denote the set of all goods that maximize the bang per buck ratio for buyer iii at the price vector p\mathbf pp. We call MBBiMBB_iMBBiâ€‹ the maximum bang per buck set (MBB set) of buyer iii at the price vector p\mathbf pp.

Fisher market equilibrium. An outcome âŸ¨x,pâŸ©\langle\mathbf x,\mathbf p\rangleâŸ¨x,pâŸ© satisfies the following conditions:

  • Market clearing: Each good is either priced at zero or is completely allocated. \forall j\in[m],p_j=0\or\sum_{i=1}^nx_{i,j}=1.
  • Budget exhaustion: Buyers spend their endowments completely. âˆ€iâˆˆ[n],p(xi)=ei\forall i\in[n],\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)=e_iâˆ€iâˆˆ[n],p(xiâ€‹)=eiâ€‹.
  • Maximum bang per buck allocation: Each buyerâ€™s allocation is a subset of its MBB set. xi,j>0â‡’jâˆˆMBBix_{i,j}\gt0\Rarr j\in MBB_ixi,jâ€‹>0â‡’jâˆˆMBBiâ€‹.

ğŸ¤”Proposition 1. For a Fisher market with additive valuations, any equilibrium outcome is fractionally Pareto efficient (fPO).

Price envy-freeness and its variants

  • x\mathbf xx is price envy-free (pEF) w.r.t. p\mathbf pp if for every pair of buyers i,kâˆˆ[n]i,k\in[n]i,kâˆˆ[n], we have p(xi)â‰¥p(xk)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k)p(xiâ€‹)â‰¥p(xkâ€‹). (Equivalently, ===)
  • x\mathbf xx is price envy-free up to one good (pEF1) w.r.t. p\mathbf pp for every pair of buyers i,kâˆˆ[n]i,k\in[n]i,kâˆˆ[n], there exists a good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹ s.t. p(xi)â‰¥p(xkâ•²{j})\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})p(xiâ€‹)â‰¥p(xkâ€‹â•²{j}).
  • x\mathbf xx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp for every pair of buyers i,kâˆˆ[n]i,k\in[n]i,kâˆˆ[n], there exists a good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹ s.t. (1+Ïµ)p(xi)â‰¥p(xkâ•²{j})(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})(1+Ïµ)p(xiâ€‹)â‰¥p(xkâ€‹â•²{j}).

MBB graph and alternating paths

  • MBB graph of a Fisher market instance w.r.t. p\mathbf pp is defined as a bipartite graph GGG whose vertex set consists of the set of agents [n][n][n] and goods [m][m][m]. There is an edge between agent iii and good jjj if jâˆˆMBBij\in MBB_ijâˆˆMBBiâ€‹ (called an MBB edge).
  • Given an allocation x\mathbf xx, we can augment the MBB graph by adding allocation edges. For an augmented MBB graph, we define an alternating path P=(i,j1,i1,j2,i2,â‹¯â€‰,iâ„“âˆ’1,jâ„“,k)P=(i,j_1,i_1,j_2,i_2,\cdots,i_{\ell-1},j_\ell,k)P=(i,j1â€‹,i1â€‹,j2â€‹,i2â€‹,â‹¯,iâ„“âˆ’1â€‹,jâ„“â€‹,k) from agent iii to agent kkk as a series of alternating MBB and allocation edges s.t. j1âˆˆMBBiâˆ©xi1,j2âˆˆMBBi1âˆ©xi2,â‹¯â€‰,jâ„“âˆˆMBBiâ„“âˆ’1âˆ©xkj_1\in MBB_i\cap \mathbf x_{i_1},j_2\in MBB_{i_1}\cap\mathbf x_{i_2},\cdots,j_\ell\in MBB_{i_{\ell-1}}\cap\mathbf x_kj1â€‹âˆˆMBBiâ€‹âˆ©xi1â€‹â€‹,j2â€‹âˆˆMBBi1â€‹â€‹âˆ©xi2â€‹â€‹,â‹¯,jâ„“â€‹âˆˆMBBiâ„“âˆ’1â€‹â€‹âˆ©xkâ€‹. If such a path exists, we say that the agent kkk is reachable from agent iii via an alternating path. No agent or good is allowed to repeat in an alternating path. The path PPP is of length 2â„“2\ell2â„“ since it consists of â„“\ellâ„“ MBB edges and â„“\ellâ„“ MBB edges and â„“\ellâ„“ allocation edges.

ç®€å•ç†è§£ä¸€ä¸‹ï¼ŒMBB å›¾å°±æ˜¯åªå«æœ‰ MBB é›†åˆä¸­å¯¹åº”å…³ç³»çš„è¾¹ã€‚

è€Œå¢å¼º MBB å›¾åœ¨æ­¤åŸºç¡€ä¸ŠåŠ å…¥äº†åˆ†é…è¾¹ã€‚

å¯è¾¾æ€§æŒ‡çš„æ˜¯åœ¨å¢å¼ºå›¾ä¸Šå¦‚æœä¸€ä¸ªæ™ºèƒ½ä½“èŠ‚ç‚¹ç»è¿‡ä¸€ä¸ªæ›¿æ¢è·¯å¾„å¯ä»¥åˆ°å¦ä¸€ä¸ªæ™ºèƒ½ä½“èŠ‚ç‚¹ã€‚

Hierarchy structure

  • Let GGG denote the augmented MBB graph for a Fisher market instance with the market outcome (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p).

  • Fix a source agent iâˆˆ[n]i\in[n]iâˆˆ[n] in GGG. Define the level of an agent kkk as half the length of the shortest alternating path from iii to kkk. The level of the source agent iii is defined to be 000. If there is no alternating path from iii to some agent kkk in GGG, then the level of kkk is set to be nnn. The hierarchy structure Hi\mathcal H_iHiâ€‹ of agent iii is defined as a level-wise collection of all agents that are reachable from iii, where Hiâ„“\mathcal H_i^\ellHiâ„“â€‹ denotes the set of agents that are at level â„“\ellâ„“ w.r.t. the agent iii. BuildHierarchy is used for constructing such a hierarchy.

    In a hierarchy cannot have edges between agents at the same level.

Violators

  • An agent iii with smallest spending money among all the agents is called least spender, i.e., iâˆˆargâ¡minâ¡kâˆˆ[n]p(xk)i\in\arg\min_{k\in[n]}\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k)iâˆˆargminkâˆˆ[n]â€‹p(xkâ€‹). An agent kâˆˆ[n]k\in[n]kâˆˆ[n] is said to be a violator if for every good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹, we have p(xkâ•²{j})>p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\gt\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xkâ€‹â•²{j})>p(xiâ€‹), where iii is the least spender.

  • Analogously, kkk is said to be Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-violator if for every good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹, we have p(xkâ•²{j})>(1+Ïµ)p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\gt(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xkâ€‹â•²{j})>(1+Ïµ)p(xiâ€‹). An agent can be a violator without being an Ïµ\epsilonÏµ violator.

    æ‰€ä»¥Îµ-è¿åè€…æ¯”è¿åè€…æ›´è‹›åˆ»ï¼Ÿ

  • If no agent is a violator (or Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-violator), then the allocation x\mathbf xx is pEF1 (Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-pEF1) w.r.t. p\mathbf pp.

Path-violator

  • Let iii denote the least spender, and let Hi\mathcal H_iHiâ€‹ denote the hierarchy of agent iii. An agent kâˆˆHik\in\mathcal H_ikâˆˆHiâ€‹ is said to be path-violator w.r.t. the alternating path P=(i,j1,i1,j2,i2,â‹¯â€‰,iâ„“âˆ’1,jâ„“,k)P=(i,j_1,i_1,j_2,i_2,\cdots,i_{\ell-1},j_\ell,k)P=(i,j1â€‹,i1â€‹,j2â€‹,i2â€‹,â‹¯,iâ„“âˆ’1â€‹,jâ„“â€‹,k) if p(xkâ•²{jâ„“})>p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j_\ell\})\gt\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xkâ€‹â•²{jâ„“â€‹})>p(xiâ€‹).
  • A path-violator need not be a violator, since there can be a good jâˆˆxkj\in\mathbf x_kjâˆˆxkâ€‹ not on the path PPP s.t. p(xkâ•²{j})â‰¤p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\le\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xkâ€‹â•²{j})â‰¤p(xiâ€‹). Similarly, an agent kâˆˆHik\in\mathcal H_ikâˆˆHiâ€‹ is said to be an Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-path-violator w.r.t. PPP if p(xkâ•²{jâ„“})>(1+Ïµ)p(xi)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j_\ell\})\gt(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)p(xkâ€‹â•²{jâ„“â€‹})>(1+Ïµ)p(xiâ€‹).

Description of the Algorithm

Given any fair division instance III as input and a parameter Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt0Ïµ>0. constructs a market equilibrium (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) w.r.t. a Fisher market instance âŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V,\mathbf e\rangleâŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ©. The pair (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) has the following two properties:

  1. x\mathbf xx is an integral allocation.

  2. x\mathcal xx is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp.

    This shows that the allocation x\mathbf xx is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-EF1 for the corresponding fair division instance I\mathcal II.

By proposition 1, the allocation x\mathbf xx is guaranteed to be fractionally Pareto Optimal for the Fisher market instance, and consequently for the fair division instance I\mathcal II.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 2. Let Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt0Ïµ>0, and let x\mathbf xx and p\mathbf pp be an allocation and a price vector respectively for a market instance âŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V,\mathbf e\rangleâŸ¨[n],[m],V,eâŸ© s.t.

  1. x\mathbf xx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-pEF1.
  2. xiâˆˆMBBi\mathbf x_i\in MBB_ixiâ€‹âˆˆMBBiâ€‹ for each player iâˆˆ[n]i\in[n]iâˆˆ[n].

Then, x\mathbf xx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-EF1 for the associated fair division instance âŸ¨[n],[m],VâŸ©\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V\rangleâŸ¨[n],[m],VâŸ©.

Since x\mathbf xx is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp, for any pair of buyers i,kâˆˆ[n]i,k\in[n]i,kâˆˆ[n], âˆƒjâˆˆxk\exist j\in\mathbf x_kâˆƒjâˆˆxkâ€‹ s.t. (1+Ïµ)p(xi)â‰¥p(xkâ•²{j})(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})(1+Ïµ)p(xiâ€‹)â‰¥p(xkâ€‹â•²{j}).

Multiplying both sides with maximum bang per ratio Î±i\alpha_iÎ±iâ€‹ for agent iii, we have

Î±i(1+Ïµ)p(xi)â‰¥Î±ip(xkâ•²{j})â‡’(1+Ïµ)vi(xi)â‰¥Î±ip(xkâ•²{j})âˆµxiâŠ†MBBiâ‡’(1+Ïµ)vi(xi)â‰¥vi(xkâ•²{j}),\alpha_i(1+\epsilon)\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)\ge\alpha_i\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\\\Rarr(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbf x_i)\ge\alpha_i\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\})\because\mathbf x_i\subseteq MBB_i\\\Rarr(1+\epsilon)v_i(\mathbf x_i)\ge v_i(\mathbf x_k\diagdown\{j\}),Î±iâ€‹(1+Ïµ)p(xiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±iâ€‹p(xkâ€‹â•²{j})â‡’(1+Ïµ)viâ€‹(xiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±iâ€‹p(xkâ€‹â•²{j})âˆµxiâ€‹âŠ†MBBiâ€‹â‡’(1+Ïµ)viâ€‹(xiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(xkâ€‹â•²{j}),

which is the Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-EF1 guarantee for the allocation x\mathbf xx.

The algorithmâ€™s behavior:

  • Phase 1: starts with a welfare maximizing allocation x\mathbf xx and p\mathbf pp s.t. x\mathbf xx is fPO and each agent gets a subset of its MBB goods. If the allocation x\mathbf xx is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1 w.r.t. p\mathbf pp, then the algorithm terminates with the output (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p). Otherwise, goto phase 2.

  • Phase 2: the algorithm works with hierarchy of the least spending agent, and performs a series of exchanges (or swaps) of goods between the agents in the hierarchy. The swaps are aimed at ensuring that at the end of Phase 2, no agent in the hierarchy is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-pEF1 envied by the least spender.

    All exchanges happen only along the MBB edges, thus maintaining at each stage the condition that x\mathbf xx is an equilibrium allocation, and hence fPO.

    If at the end of Phase 2, the current allocation x\mathbf xx is still not 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1 w.r.t. the price vector p\mathbf pp, the algorithm move to Phase 3.

  • Phase 3: Uniformly raising the price of the goods owned by the members of the hierarchy. The price are raised until either the allocation x\mathbf xx becomes 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1 w.r.t. the new price vector p\mathbf pp, or a new agent gets added to the hierarchy. In the latter case, the algorithm goes back to the start of Phase 2.

Establishing the time complexity for this algorithm is complicated. The stated running time bound is obtained via a number of involved arguments relying on analyzing the spending of the agents in different phases.

Proof of Theorem 1

Seems that I have no time to understand the detail.

I try to grasp the argument of proof.

First we should present the analysis of algorithm for valuations that satisfy the power of (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ) property. Then extend the analysis to general valuations.

Pseudo-code

Input: A fair division instance I\mathcal II s.t. valuations are power-of-(1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ)

Output: An integral allocation x\mathbf xx and a price vector p\mathbf pp.

  3. if (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1 then return it

(1+Ïµ)s>p(xh)p(xi)(1+\epsilon)^s\gt\frac{\mathbf p(\mathbf x_h)}{\mathbf p(\mathbf x_i)}(1+Ïµ)s>p(xiâ€‹)p(xhâ€‹)â€‹. here iii is the least spender and hâˆˆargâ¡minâ¡kâˆˆ[n]â•²Hip(xk)h\in\arg\min_{k\in[n]\diagdown\mathcal H_i}\mathbf p(\mathbf x_k)hâˆˆargminkâˆˆ[n]â•²Hiâ€‹â€‹p(xkâ€‹).

  6. if Î±=Î±2\alpha=\alpha_2Î±=Î±2â€‹ then return (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) else repeat Phase 2 starting from line 4

Analysis of ALG when the Valuations are power-of-(1+Îµ)

power-of-(1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ): âˆƒÏµ>0\exist\epsilon\gt0âˆƒÏµ>0, s.t. âˆ€iâˆˆ[n],jâˆˆ[m]:vi,jâˆˆ{0,(1+Ïµ)a}\forall i\in[n],j\in[m]:v_{i,j}\in\{0,(1+\epsilon)^a\}âˆ€iâˆˆ[n],jâˆˆ[m]:vi,jâ€‹âˆˆ{0,(1+Ïµ)a} for some natural number aaa.

Time step and events. 4 events:

  1. Swap in Phase 2
  2. Change in the identity of least spender in Phase 2
  3. Prise-rise by a factor of Î±\alphaÎ± in Phase 3
  4. Termination step.

Denote time step the indexing of any execution of ALG.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 3. Given any power-of-(1+Ïµ1+\epsilon1+Ïµ) instance as input, the allocation returned by ALG is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-EF1 and fPO.

fPO: observation: at each step, the allocation of any agent is a subset of its MMB goods.

Step 1: true (by way of setting prices).

Step 2: swap operation only happens along an alternating MBB-allocation edge which maintains MBB condition.

Step 3: raising the prices of goods owned by the members of hierarchy Hi\mathcal H_iHiâ€‹ without changing the allocation. ARGUMENT

Then define a Fisher market where each agentâ€™s endowment equals its spending under x\mathbf xx. Since (x,p)(\mathbf x,\mathbf p)(x,p) is an equilibrium, x\mathbf xx is fPO.

Next, argue that x\mathbf xx is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-EF1. The ALG terminates only if either 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1, or Î±=Î±2\alpha=\alpha_2Î±=Î±2â€‹. If Î±=Î±2\alpha=\alpha_2Î±=Î±2â€‹, we need to argue itâ€™s 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-pEF1. omitted

ğŸ¤”Lemma 4. Given any power-of-(1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ) instance as input, ALG terminates in time \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) where v_\max=\max_{i,j}v_{i,j}.

Proof omitted.

Analysis of ALG for General Valuations: Proof of Theorem 1

Show that for any given fair division instance I\mathcal II with integral valuations, EF1 + PO allocation can be found in pseudo-polynomial time.

Proof by running ALG on Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-rounded version Iâ€²=âŸ¨[n],[m],Vâ€²âŸ©\mathcal I'=\langle[n],[m],\mathcal V'\rangleIâ€²=âŸ¨[n],[m],Vâ€²âŸ© of the given instance I\mathcal II for some parameter Ïµ>0\epsilon\gt0Ïµ>0. The Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² is a power-of-(1+Ïµ1+\epsilon1+Ïµ) instance constructed by rounding up the valuations in I\mathcal II to the nearest integer power of (1+Ïµ)(1+\epsilon)(1+Ïµ). From Lemma 3, we know this allocation is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-EF1 and fPO w.r.t. Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€². Then it remians to show that for an appropriate choice of Ïµ\epsilonÏµ, the same allocation turns out to be EF1 + PO w.r.t. I\mathcal II.

In addition, the running time bound in Lemma 4 instantiated for the choice of Ïµ\epsilonÏµ shows that ALG runs in pseudo-polynomial time.

for each agent iii, the valuation is replaced by

vi,jâ‰¤vi,jâ€²â‰¤(1+Ïµ)vi,jv_{i,j}\le v'_{i,j}\le(1+\epsilon)v_{i,j}vi,jâ€‹â‰¤vi,jâ€²â€‹â‰¤(1+Ïµ)vi,jâ€‹ for each i,ji,ji,j.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 5. Let I\mathcal II be a fair division instance. Let \epsilon\le\frac{1}{6m^3v^4_\max}. Then, an allocation x\mathbf xx that is fPO for Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² is PO for I\mathcal II.

Lemma 5 establishes for an appropriate choice of Ïµ\epsilonÏµ, an allocation that is fPO for the Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-rounded instance Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² is PO w.r.t. the original instance I\mathcal II.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 6. Let I\mathcal II be a fair division instance, and let 0\lt\delta\lt\frac{1}{2mv_\max} Then, an allocation x\mathbf xx is Î´\deltaÎ´-EF1 for I\mathcal II iff it is EF1 for I\mathcal II.

Omitted.

The proof of Theorem 1:

  • Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² is Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-rounded version of I\mathcal II with \epsilon=\frac{1}{14m^3v^4_\max}. From Lemma 3 and 4, x\mathcal xx is 3Ïµ3\epsilon3Ïµ-EF1 and fPO for Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² can be found in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) time.
  • Under this choice, by lemma 5, x\mathbf xx must be PO for I\mathcal II. Thus x\mathbf xx is EF1.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 7. Given the Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-rounded version Iâ€²\mathcal I'Iâ€² as input, ALG finds a 7Ïµ7\epsilon7Ïµ-EF1 and Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-PO allocation for I\mathcal II in \mathcal O(\text{poly}(m,n,\frac{1}{\epsilon},\ln v_\max)) time.

I am lost.

Theorem 2 EF1+fPO

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 2. Given any fair division instance with additive valuations, there always exists an allocation that is EF1 and fPO.

\epsilon_z=\frac{1}{14zm^3v^4_\max},z\in\mathbb N.

Suffocating.

Theorem 3 Nash Social Welfare Approximation

ALG provides 1.45â‰ˆe1/e1.45\approx e^{1/e}1.45â‰ˆe1/e-approximation for Nash social welfare maximization in polynomial time.

Use lemma 8 to prove lemma 1.

ğŸ¤”Lemma 8. Let I\mathcal II be an instance with additive and identical valuation functions s.t. mâ‰¥nm\ge nmâ‰¥n. Let BâŠ‚[m]B\sub[m]BâŠ‚[m] be a subset of goods s.t. âˆ£Bâˆ£<n|B|\lt nâˆ£Bâˆ£<n. Then, there is a partially-fractional allocation Ï‰âˆˆFB\omega\in\mathcal F_BÏ‰âˆˆFBâ€‹ that maximize Nash social welfare among allocations in FB\mathcal F_BFBâ€‹ s.t.

  1. Each agent gets at most one goods from BBB under Ï‰\omegaÏ‰.
  2. Any agent with strictly-better-than-the-worst allocation under Ï‰\omegaÏ‰ gets exactly one integral good. That is, for any agent iâˆˆ[n]i\in[n]iâˆˆ[n] s.t. v(Ï‰i)>minâ¡kv(Ï‰k)v(\omega_i)\gt\min_kv(\omega_k)v(Ï‰iâ€‹)>minkâ€‹v(Ï‰kâ€‹), we have Ï‰i,j=1\omega_{i,j}=1Ï‰i,jâ€‹=1 for some jâˆˆBj\in BjâˆˆB and Ï‰i,jâ€²=0\omega_{i,j'}=0Ï‰i,jâ€²â€‹=0 for all jâ€²â‰ jj'\neq jjâ€²î€ =j.

Property 2. proved by contradiction.

Property 1. proved by swap operation.

Proof of lemma 1: Too difficult.

ğŸ¯ğŸ¤”Theorem 3. For additive valuations, there exists a polynomial-time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for the Nash social welfare maximization problem.

omitted.

Conclusion

Based on integral Fisher markets and approximate pEF condition

Psudo-polynomial algorithm for finding EF1 and PO

Poly time 1.451.451.45-approximation algorithm for Nash social welfare.

Future work:

  • Does there exist polynomial time algorithm for EF1 + PO?
  • How about more general classes of valuations?
entry.summary:
Objective: Investigate methods for computing allocations satisfying both EF1 and PO.

Activities: Review the paper

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 9 Graph Embedding
entry.content:
Main problem with graphs: lack of predefined node ordering.

Graph is non-Euclidean: the distance among two nodes does not depend on the coordinates of the nodes.

Origin idea of graph embedding: graph could become a set of multi-dimensional points in which Euclidean distances represent similarities among the nodes.

2 methods of embedding:

  1. Linear embedding: linear transformation of the edges.
  2. Random-walk embedding: preserving the probability that a node is reachable from another node.

Linear Embeddings

Simplest form of graph embeddings.

Let ziâˆˆRd\mathbf z_i\in\mathbb R^dziâ€‹âˆˆRd the embedding vector of the node iii.

The similarity between vector zi,zj\mathbf z_i,\mathbf z_jziâ€‹,zjâ€‹ is sim(i,j)â‰ˆziâŠ¤â‹…zjsim(i,j)\approx\mathbf z_i^\top\cdot\mathbf z_jsim(i,j)â‰ˆziâŠ¤â€‹â‹…zjâ€‹. If two nodes are â€œcloseâ€ under some definition of similarity, they should be also similar in the embedding space.

To define embedding vectors, we need

  1. An encoder from nodes to the embedding space.
  2. A similarity among nodes in the graph.

Then we need to define an objective or loss function, s.t. the embeddings are the parameters of optimization. Depending on the loss function, we can then use the appropriate optimizer to find the embeddings zi\mathbf z_iziâ€‹

Shallow encoding. We define the embedding matrix ZnÃ—d\mathbf Z^{n\times d}ZnÃ—d in which row iii is the embedding zi\mathbf z_iziâ€‹ of node iii. Given Z\mathbf ZZ we can encode each node in its corresponding embedding by a lookup on the embedding matrix. Let vâˆˆIn\mathbf v\in\mathbb I^nvâˆˆIn the indicator vector that has a 111 in position iii and 000 otherwise. Then

zi=ZâŠ¤v\mathbf z_i=\mathbf Z^\top\mathbf vziâ€‹=ZâŠ¤v

Node similarity. Intuitively check whether two nodes connected, are far form each other in shortest-path, are reachable from random walk, or simply share any common information.

Adjacency-based Similarity

The simplest: two nodes are similar if they share an edge between them.

sim(i,j)=aijsim(i,j)=a_{ij}sim(i,j)=aijâ€‹ implies the dot-product among the embedding vectors should approximate the entries of the adjacency matrix aijâ‰ˆziâŠ¤zja_{ij}\approx\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jaijâ€‹â‰ˆziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹.

We then find embedding that minimize the distance among the entries aija_{ij}aijâ€‹ and the dot-product among the embedding vectors ziâŠ¤zj\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹:

L=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ£ziâŠ¤zjâˆ’aijâˆ£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-a_{ij}|^2L=(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹âˆ’aijâ€‹âˆ£2

which corresponds to the minimization of the norm between A\mathbf AA and the matrix ZZâŠ¤,âˆ£âˆ£ZZâŠ¤âˆ’Aâˆ£âˆ£F2\mathbf{ZZ^\top},||\mathbf{ZZ^\top-\mathbf A||}_F^2ZZâŠ¤,âˆ£âˆ£ZZâŠ¤âˆ’Aâˆ£âˆ£F2â€‹.

In order to minimize the objective, we use gradient descent or matrix decomposition (such as SVD or QR-decomposition) on A\mathbf AA.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  1. The similarity function is straightforward
  2. Many methods for solving the optimization problem.

ğŸ‘

  1. O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2) running time to consider all pairs, O(âˆ£Eâˆ£)\mathcal O(|E|)O(âˆ£Eâˆ£) if we sum only over the non-zero entries.
  2. O(dn)\mathcal O(dn)O(dn) parameters, one vector for each node.
  3. Only consider direct and local connections through the adjacency matrix.

Multi-hop Similarity

Connections at distance kkk from a certain node to remedy to the strict requirements of the adjacency-based similarity.

The kkk-th power of the adjacency matrix captures kkk-hop connections. Indeed the position i,ji,ji,j in Ak\mathbf A^kAk represents the number of paths of lengths kkk from node iii to node jjj.

Similarly to the case above loss function minimizes the differences between the entry i,ji,ji,j in the kkk-th power of the adjacency matrix and the dot-product among the embedding vectors of the nodes i,ji,ji,j.

L=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ£ziâŠ¤zjâˆ’aijkâˆ£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-a_{ij}^k|^2L=(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹âˆ’aijkâ€‹âˆ£2

Similarly, this corresponds to minimizing âˆ£âˆ£ZâŠ¤Zâˆ’Akâˆ£âˆ£F2||\mathbf{Z^\top Z}-\mathbf A^k||_F^2âˆ£âˆ£ZâŠ¤Zâˆ’Akâˆ£âˆ£F2â€‹. In practice, to avoid numerical explosion, GraRep use a log-transformed probabilistic adjacency matrix

a~ijk=maxâ¡{logâ¡(aij/diâˆ‘lâˆˆV(alj/dl))kâˆ’Î±,0}\tilde a_{ij}^k=\max\{\log(\frac{a_{ij}/d_i}{\sum_{l\in V}(a_{lj}/d_l)})^k-\alpha,0\}a~ijkâ€‹=max{log(âˆ‘lâˆˆVâ€‹(aljâ€‹/dlâ€‹)aijâ€‹/diâ€‹â€‹)kâˆ’Î±,0}

where ddd is node degree, and Î±\alphaÎ± is a constant shift. GraRep trains embeddings with different kkk and concatenates the embedding vectors.

A more flexible option to capture multi-hop similarities relies on the overlap between node neighborhoods, using overlap functions such as Jaccard Similarity and Adamic-Adar score which is sij=âˆ‘lâˆˆN(i)âˆ©N(j)1logâ¡N(l)s_{ij}=\sum_{l\in N(i)\cap N(j)}\frac{1}{\log N(l)}sijâ€‹=âˆ‘lâˆˆN(i)âˆ©N(j)â€‹logN(l)1â€‹. The loss function becomes

L=âˆ‘(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ£ziâŠ¤zjâˆ’sijâˆ£2\mathcal L=\sum_{(i,j)\in V\times V}|\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j-s_{ij}|^2L=(i,j)âˆˆVÃ—Vâˆ‘â€‹âˆ£ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹âˆ’sijâ€‹âˆ£2

One drawback with Linear embedding is, in their current form, they require to compute the pairwise similarities for all nodes, taking O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2) in the worst case. For large graphs, a quadratic complexity is not feasible. Moreover. we need to define the similarity beforehand.

Neural Embeddings

Alternative to the pairwise computation by exploiting the efficiency of probability distributions.

Random-walk based embeddings, non-linear similarity embeddings

Random Walk Embeddings

Let ziâŠ¤zj\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_jziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹ be the probability that node iii and node jjj co-occur in a random walk over the graph. We can estimate the probability of visiting node iii from node jjj using random-walk or methods like Personalized PageRank. If we sample a large enough number of random walks. the process converges to the PageRank.

Random walks are efficient as they do not require to traverse the entire graphs, they can be easily simulated and they converge to probability distributions.

Assume we have a strategy RRR to sample random walks. We can define our embedding algorithm:

  1. Run short random walk starting from each node using strategy RRR.

  2. For each node iii, collect NR(i)N_R(i)NRâ€‹(i), the multi-set of nodes visited on random walks starting from iii

  3. Optimize the embeddings according to

    L=âˆ‘iâˆˆVâˆ‘jâˆˆNR(i)âˆ’logâ¡(p(jâˆ£zi))\mathcal L=\sum_{i\in V}\sum_{j\in N_R(i)}-\log(p(j|\mathbf z_i))L=iâˆˆVâˆ‘â€‹jâˆˆNRâ€‹(i)âˆ‘â€‹âˆ’log(p(jâˆ£ziâ€‹))

The optimization is to find embeddings that maximize the likelihood of random walk co-occurrences. We can parametrize p(jâˆ£zi)p(j|\mathbf z_i)p(jâˆ£ziâ€‹) by using softmax

p(jâˆ£zi)=expâ¡(ziâŠ¤zj)âˆ‘lâˆˆVexpâ¡(ziâŠ¤zl)p(j|\mathbf z_i)=\frac{\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}{\sum_{l\in V}\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_l)}p(jâˆ£ziâ€‹)=âˆ‘lâˆˆVâ€‹exp(ziâŠ¤â€‹zlâ€‹)exp(ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹)â€‹

The above loss can be optimized using gradient descent. However, the nested sum takes O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2), although the real bottleneck is the denominator of the probability, that sums over all nodes. One strategy to reduce the complexity is to employ a negative sampling approach.

Negative sampling treats the problem as a classification problem and splits the fraction into two parts.

logâ¡expâ¡(ziâŠ¤zj)âˆ‘lâˆˆVexpâ¡(ziâŠ¤zl)âˆ¼logâ¡(Ïƒ(ziâŠ¤zj))âˆ’âˆ‘l=1klogâ¡(zlâŠ¤znl)\log\frac{\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}{\sum_{l\in V}\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_l)}\sim\log(\sigma(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j))-\sum_{l=1}^k\log(\mathbf z_l^\top\mathbf z_{n_l})logâˆ‘lâˆˆVâ€‹exp(ziâŠ¤â€‹zlâ€‹)exp(ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹)â€‹âˆ¼log(Ïƒ(ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹))âˆ’l=1âˆ‘kâ€‹log(zlâŠ¤â€‹znlâ€‹â€‹)

where nlâˆ¼pVn_l\sim p_Vnlâ€‹âˆ¼pVâ€‹ is a node sampled from a negative distribution pVp_VpVâ€‹ over the nodes and Ïƒ\sigmaÏƒ is the sigmoid function. A typical choice of the negative distribution is to sample negative nodes proportional to the degree of each node. The more we sample, the more robust is the approximation. A higher kkk corresponds to higher prior on negative events.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  1. Expressive and non-linear
  2. Scale up with sampling techniques

ğŸ‘

  1. Similarity is fixed to random walks

General Similarities

Another approach to graph embedding is to generalize the similarity-based approaches to any samplable similarity. An appealing choice for similarity is PPR. For a given restart vector v\mathbf vv for node iii the PPR r\mathbf rr is

ri=(Iâˆ’Î±AÎ”âˆ’1)âˆ’1(1âˆ’Î±)v\mathbf r_i=(\mathbf I-\alpha\mathbf{A\Delta}^{-1})^{-1}(1-\alpha)\mathbf vriâ€‹=(Iâˆ’Î±AÎ”âˆ’1)âˆ’1(1âˆ’Î±)v

from which we obtain the PPR-matrix

S=((1âˆ’Î±)I)(Iâˆ’Î±AÎ”âˆ’1)âˆ’1\mathbf S=((1-\alpha)\mathbf I)(\mathbf I-\alpha\mathbf{A\Delta}^{-1})^{-1}S=((1âˆ’Î±)I)(Iâˆ’Î±AÎ”âˆ’1)âˆ’1

where each row iii represents the PPR vector ri\mathbf r_iriâ€‹.

One choice to embed S\mathbf SS is to use SVD; however this embedding method is again linear. We instead consider each row Si\mathbf S_iSiâ€‹ separately as probability distributions to reach any node from node iii. This is the approach of VERSE. VERSE computes the embedding matrix Z\mathbf ZZ to preserve the distribution of the similarities node by node.

VERSE optimize the KL-divergence between the distribution of node iii and node jjj, where the KL-divergence between distribution ppp and qqq is

D(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=âˆ‘xp(x)logâ¡p(x)q(x),D(p||q)=\sum_xp(x)\log\frac{p(x)}{q(x)},D(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=xâˆ‘â€‹p(x)logq(x)p(x)â€‹,

Typically, with KL-divergence the distribution ppp is fixed and given as input, while the distribution qqq is the one to learn. If that is the case, in order to learn ppp, notice that

D(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=âˆ‘xp(x)logâ¡p(x)âˆ’p(x)logâ¡q(x)D(p||q)=\sum_xp(x)\log p(x)-p(x)\log q(x)D(pâˆ£âˆ£q)=xâˆ‘â€‹p(x)logp(x)âˆ’p(x)logq(x)

Entropy of ppp minus Cross entropy

The first term, the entropy of ppp is constant if we minimize for qqq. So it suffices to reduce objective to âˆ’âˆ‘xp(x)logâ¡q(x)-\sum_x p(x)\log q(x)âˆ’âˆ‘xâ€‹p(x)logq(x).

For each node iii we can parametrize q(i)q(i)q(i) as the similarity one-to-all in embedding space given by softmax of the dot-product of the embeddings

sim(i,â‹…)=expâ¡(Zzi)âˆ‘j=1nexpâ¡(ziâŠ¤zj)sim(i,\cdot)=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{Zz}_i)}{\sum_{j=1}^n\exp(\mathbf z_i^\top\mathbf z_j)}sim(i,â‹…)=âˆ‘j=1nâ€‹exp(ziâŠ¤â€‹zjâ€‹)exp(Zziâ€‹)â€‹

Notice the numerator multiplies for the entire embedding matrix Z\mathbf ZZ. The final loss becomes

L=âˆ’âˆ‘iâˆˆVSilogâ¡sim(v,â‹…)\mathcal L=-\sum_{i\in V}\mathbf S_i\log sim(v,\cdot)L=âˆ’iâˆˆVâˆ‘â€‹Siâ€‹logsim(v,â‹…)

sim(i,â‹…)sim(i,\cdot)sim(i,â‹…) can benefit from a strategy similar to negative sampling. Another alternative is to use Noise Contrastive estimation and change the loss function into.

L=âˆ‘iâˆ¼P,jâˆ¼Si[logâ¡p(D=1âˆ£sim(i,j))+sEj~âˆ¼Q(i)logâ¡p(D=0âˆ£simE(i,j~))]\mathcal L=\sum_{i\sim\mathcal P,j\sim\mathbf S_i}[\log p(D=1|sim(i,j))+s\mathbb E_{\tilde j\sim Q(i)}\log p(D=0|sim_E(i,\tilde j))]L=iâˆ¼P,jâˆ¼Siâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹[logp(D=1âˆ£sim(i,j))+sEj~â€‹âˆ¼Q(i)â€‹logp(D=0âˆ£simEâ€‹(i,j~â€‹))]
